BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 28, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MUSICIANS SCORE BIG SUCCESS

MAKES PLEA BEFORE COMMITTEE

Musical Clubs' Concert One of Best Ever
Given—Every Number Wins Applause—Crowd Exceptionally Large.

Pres. Goodnow, Mr. Griswold and Hopkins Trustees Appear Before Maryland Legislature to Atli State .
to Continue Grant.

With two of the best musical
clubs Hopkins has ever turned out,
with a large and appreciative audience, and with an unusually enjoyable dance as its final feature, the
, McCoy Hall Concert last Friday
night justified j every prediction
which had been made for its success. It is doubtful if a better concert has ever been given in the entire history of the clubs.
Especial credit should be given to
the Board of Managers for their
work in arranging the concert. The
large crowd was ample evidence of
the efficient advertising which had
been done, and the arrangements
throughout gave proof of careful
and thorough organization.
The program of the concert was
as follows:

The trustees of Johns Hopkins
University appeared last Thursday
before the joint meeting of the corn:mittee of the Maryland Legislature making up the Appropriation
Bill, and a plea was made by President Goodnow and B. Howell Griswold for the continuation s of the
annual State appropriation to the
University.
This appropriation usually
amounts to about $25,00o a year
and is given, usually without restriction, for the benefit of the
whole institution. In recent years
the legislature has made an appropriation of $5o,000 a year for
scholarships given in the school of
technology. The enlargement or at
least the continuation of this endowment was the keynote of the
speeches made by the members of
the delegation. The seriousness of
the situation was depicted especially
when this department, which is'so
young as to have not had a graduating class, had not received the proper financial support and attention
which it deserves.
Referring to the justification of
granting 'these appropriations,
President Goodnow stated that the
tuition fees contributed only about
25 per cent. of Hopkins' revenue.
On the other hand, he pointed out,
in the undergraduate department
94 out of every 'Po students are
Maryland boys; while in the school
of technology 145 out of the 148
enrolled are natives of this State.
The proportion taking graduate
work, of course, is much less, but
even here many students from
Maryland take advantage of the
opportunity offered in this institution for advanced instruction.
President Goodnow was upKoar-,_
iously applauded when he replied to
a query, that from the viewpoint
of those charged with the dilstribution of the State appropriations
he believed that they shoul4 be
discontinued; but, on the other
hand, reviewing all phases of the
question from a purely educational
standpoint, he thought that the
State officials could not persuade
themselves to look other than
favorably upon the matter.

Every number of the program
met with prolonged applause, and
only a consideration of the ,dance
which was scheduled to come after
the concert prevented the demand
for an encore after every selection
from being granted. Yet even with
this in mind, the clubs were obliged
to return to the stage after at least
half of the numbers.
Both Glee and Mandolin Clubs
were in remarkably good shape.
The Glee Club was well balanced,
with good voices in every part. It
showed good knowledge of the
technique of mass singing; the
tones, even in the most subdued
pianissimos, were rich and. mellow.

GEORGETOWN DEBATERS WIN

FOR LAYFIELD MEMORIAL FUND

Team of Adams Literary Society Defeated by That of Philodemic Society—Debate Held in
Washington.

Petition to Be Circulated About University to Secure Funds for Memorial
at Homewood,to Be Erected
Sometime in Future.

The representatives of the Adams
Literary Society 'of this University
were defeated in a debate last Saturday night by the team of the
Philodemic Society of Georgetown
College. .
The debate, which was held at
Georgetown, was attended by a
large crowd, and was hotly contested by both sides. Both teams acquitted themselves we.l, the Georgetown debaters especially displaying
both remarkable knowsedge of the
subject and extremely good delivery.
The subject was: "Resolved,
That the President of the United
States should be elected to a single
term of six years." The Philodemic
defended the affirmative, while the
Adams upheld the negative.
Those on the Adams' team were:
Robert R. Duncan, Reuben Oppenheimer and Thomas J. Tingley,,
with Ira B. Fader as alternate. The
Philodemic was represented by
John J. Darby, Edward J. Callahan
and Rufus S. Lusk. Each man
made a speech of ten minutes and
a rebuttal of five.
The judges were Hon. Robert M.
Montgomery, Presiding Judge United States Court of Customs Appeals; Willard H. Bronson, Rear
Admiral United States Navy: Hon.
Charles H. Robb, Associate Justice
Court of Appeals, District of Columbia; Hon. Walter I. McCoy, Associate Judge. Supreme Court, District of Columbia; and Hon. James
F. Smith, Associate Judge United
States ,Court of ..Customs Appeals.

The following petition is now being circulated about the University:
"Last year it was the unanimous
sentiment of the Student-Body that
a permanent memorial to Bobby
Layfield should be erected. Because
of the indefinite nature of the University building plans, it was impossible to do so at that time. The
same conditions now exist, but the
following committee appointed by
the Athletic Association feel that
the funds for the memorial should
be collected at the present time
while those who knew Layfield are
still connected with the University.
"Accordingly, at the suggestion
of President Keyser of the Board
of Trustees, the present campaign
is now being made, the resulting
fund to be invested by the trustees
with the understanding that the
permanent memorial of suitable
design is to be erected at the earliest possible time.
"THEODORE STRAUS,
"HIRAM W. WOODWARD,
"FRANKLIN W. SUTTON,
"Committee."
There is no set sum to be given
by the students, and no definite
amount stipplated for each individual contribution. . The smallest
contributions will be as welcome as
the largest; the committee feels that
it is the thought inspired by this
rembrance of Lay-field, and which
will be perpetuated in the memorial,
which is the essential thing.

Besides the individual contributions, sums will be donated by the
Athletic Association, THE NEWSLETTER and other student organizations.

New Material to Be Tested at George
Washington Meet—Relay to Be Main
Event—Coach England Urges
All to Avoid Black List.
A large number of entries has
been made by the Johns Hopkins
track team in the eighth annual
indoor meet of the George Washington University, at Convention
Hall, in Washington, on Saturday,
March 4.
Coach England has decided that
he will send over an almost entirely new collection of runners, so
that all the promising members of
the track team may have experience
in indoor racing. Consequently,
with the exception of the relay
team and a few other men, Hopkins
will be almost entirely represented
by novices,
The most important event of the
meet will be the relay race between
Hopkins and Georgetown. Providing Uhler and Fred Hall recover
from the slight injuries they received in the Georgetown University meet, and that the other members of the relay team keep in good
shape, the event should result in a
walk-away for this University. The
relay team will be made up of F.
Hall, Uhler, Straus, P. Sutton, and
Dempster as first substitute.
Next in interest to the relay to
Hopkins men will be the South
Atlantic Inter-Collegiate Athletic
Association events, particularly the
two-mile run, in which Perkins,
E. L. Smith, Weeks, Holtz and Bullard will run for Hopkins. Considering the recent abLity displayed
by Weeks and Perkins, Hopkins
should win one or all of the first
three places in this event. Likewise, Hopkins is practically sure of
winning a number of points in the
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association 44o-yard dash,
since Sutton, Straus and Uhler will
be entered.
The entries in the George Washington meet are as follows: Those
entered for long distances are Bullard in the South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association 2-mile
run, Weeks in I-mi.e and 2-mile
open events, A. A. Weech, Fred
Hall and Holtz in the I-mile open
event, Edgett and Kaufman in the
88o-yard run, and E. L. Smith and
J. T. Thompson in the 600-yard
run. In the open 440-yard dash
Dempster, Firor, E. G. Hall,
Stevenson and P. Sutton will run.
Uhler and Pfitsch will sprint for
Hopkins in the South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association
440-yard dash. Those entered in
the 50-yard hurdles are Dempster
and J. T. Thompson. Besides running on the relay. Straus will also
enter the 50-yard dash. The other
entries are Lyman and Stevenson in
the pole-vault, Firor in the highjump, and Tddings and Sonneborn
in the shot-put.Last Thursday Coach England
gave an informal talk to the entire

The Mandolin Club, which for

and drums was absent, the club was

background against which the clear
tones of the first mandolins stood

Perhaps the most appreciated

singing of the quartette. Composed
of four extraordinarily good voices,
all well trained, it gave its first selection, "Luella Lee," with such
striking feeling and harmony that
the audience would not be satisfied

this encore, the quartette gave
"Johnny Smoker," and again met
with uproarious success.

Dr. Buchner at Detroit Convention.

Dr. Edward F. Buchner took a
prominent part recently in the convention of the Consolidated Educational Associations held at Detroit.
This convention sums up the work
done in all lines of education during
the preceding year, and is the most
important function of its kind held
in the country.
Dr. Buchner, during the convention, acted as secretary of the Committee on Resolutions of the Department of Superintendence of the
National Educational Association.
After his return from the convention, Dr. Buchner went to the
University of Michigan, where he
was the chief speaker at the Hopkins Alumni celebration.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 28, 1916.

TOCQUEVILLE TRY-OUTS FRIDAY

BASKET-BALL GAMES NEAR END

Preliminary Contest to be Held to Restrict
Number of Participants in Final
Combat —Only Five-Minute
Speeches Necessary.

Freshman Team Still Heads Interclass
League—Juniori Defeat Sophomores,
and Freshmen Win Against
the Senior Class.

The preliminary contest for the
Tocqueville medal will be held this
Friday at 12, in the Donovan
Room. Four men will be selected
from the participants in these tryouts, and these will compete in
the final contest on Friday, March
31.
In the preliminary trial, it is only
necessary to make a five-minute
speech. The same rules hold for
these speeches, however, as have
been announced for the final competition. The speeches are to be
less general and less emotional
than the general type of orations,
and are each to be limited to a
single topic. While the medal is
to be awarded for excellence in
public speaking, both preliminary
and final contests will differ from
a debate in not being directly controversial.
All those who intend to compete
in the try-outs on Friday should
immediately hand their names to
Dr. French, if they have not already
done so.
The subject for the entire contest will be "The Overthrow of
the Second Republic and the Coup
d'Etat." Specimen sub-topics, which
have been announced as available
for the preliminary contest, are as
follows:
The Causes of the Revolution of
1848.
The Regime of Guigot.
The Personality of Louis Philippe.
Lamartine and the Revolution.
The Republic and the Workingman.
Socialism and the Revolution.
Adolphe Thiers and the Republic.
The Freedom of the Press.
Victor Hugo and the Republic.
"The Napoleonic Ides" in 1848.
Louis Napoleon as a'Republican.

Owing to the fact that the majority of men on the teams of the
inter-class basket-ball league did
not make their appearance in the
gymnasium on February, 22, all
games for that day were postponed.
For this reason the series will not
end until Tuesday and Thursday of
this week.
On Thursday, February 24, two
scheduled games of the series were
played. The first game was between the juniors and sophomores.
This game was quite devoid of any
spectacular features. The juniors
winning by an overwhelming score
of 28 to 7, outplayed their opponents in every particular. Baker,
for the juniors, scored six goals
Love made the majority of points
for the sophomores.
The next game, that between the
seniors and freshmen, was closely
contested. The seniors, as in previous games, did their good playing
in the first half. At the beginning
of the second half the score stood
7 to 9 in favor of the freshmen.
From this point on, the seniors began to weaken and the freshmen
developed an unusual burst of
speed. During this half Cox made
a fine field goal for the freshmen.
Many chances were given the seniors to score in this period, but their
ability to shoot was not equal to
their opportunities. The freshmen
won by the score of 17 to 12.
The freshmen are still at the
head of the league. The standing
of the teams is as follows:

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 28, 1916.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MUSICIANS SCORE BIG SUCCESS

MAKES PLEA BEFORE COMMITTEE

Musical Clubs' Concert One of Best Ever
Given—Every Number Wins Applause—Crowd Exceptionally Large.

Pres. Goodnow, Mr. Griswold and Hopkins Trustees Appear Before Maryland Legislature to Atli State .
to Continue Grant.

With two of the best musical
clubs Hopkins has ever turned out,
with a large and appreciative audience, and with an unusually enjoyable dance as its final feature, the
, McCoy Hall Concert last Friday
night justified j every prediction
which had been made for its success. It is doubtful if a better concert has ever been given in the entire history of the clubs.
Especial credit should be given to
the Board of Managers for their
work in arranging the concert. The
large crowd was ample evidence of
the efficient advertising which had
been done, and the arrangements
throughout gave proof of careful
and thorough organization.
The program of the concert was
as follows:

The trustees of Johns Hopkins
University appeared last Thursday
before the joint meeting of the corn:mittee of the Maryland Legislature making up the Appropriation
Bill, and a plea was made by President Goodnow and B. Howell Griswold for the continuation s of the
annual State appropriation to the
University.
This appropriation usually
amounts to about $25,00o a year
and is given, usually without restriction, for the benefit of the
whole institution. In recent years
the legislature has made an appropriation of $5o,000 a year for
scholarships given in the school of
technology. The enlargement or at
least the continuation of this endowment was the keynote of the
speeches made by the members of
the delegation. The seriousness of
the situation was depicted especially
when this department, which is'so
young as to have not had a graduating class, had not received the proper financial support and attention
which it deserves.
Referring to the justification of
granting 'these appropriations,
President Goodnow stated that the
tuition fees contributed only about
25 per cent. of Hopkins' revenue.
On the other hand, he pointed out,
in the undergraduate department
94 out of every 'Po students are
Maryland boys; while in the school
of technology 145 out of the 148
enrolled are natives of this State.
The proportion taking graduate
work, of course, is much less, but
even here many students from
Maryland take advantage of the
opportunity offered in this institution for advanced instruction.
President Goodnow was upKoar-,_
iously applauded when he replied to
a query, that from the viewpoint
of those charged with the dilstribution of the State appropriations
he believed that they shoul4 be
discontinued; but, on the other
hand, reviewing all phases of the
question from a purely educational
standpoint, he thought that the
State officials could not persuade
themselves to look other than
favorably upon the matter.

Every number of the program
met with prolonged applause, and
only a consideration of the ,dance
which was scheduled to come after
the concert prevented the demand
for an encore after every selection
from being granted. Yet even with
this in mind, the clubs were obliged
to return to the stage after at least
half of the numbers.
Both Glee and Mandolin Clubs
were in remarkably good shape.
The Glee Club was well balanced,
with good voices in every part. It
showed good knowledge of the
technique of mass singing; the
tones, even in the most subdued
pianissimos, were rich and. mellow.

GEORGETOWN DEBATERS WIN

FOR LAYFIELD MEMORIAL FUND

Team of Adams Literary Society Defeated by That of Philodemic Society—Debate Held in
Washington.

Petition to Be Circulated About University to Secure Funds for Memorial
at Homewood,to Be Erected
Sometime in Future.

The representatives of the Adams
Literary Society 'of this University
were defeated in a debate last Saturday night by the team of the
Philodemic Society of Georgetown
College. .
The debate, which was held at
Georgetown, was attended by a
large crowd, and was hotly contested by both sides. Both teams acquitted themselves we.l, the Georgetown debaters especially displaying
both remarkable knowsedge of the
subject and extremely good delivery.
The subject was: "Resolved,
That the President of the United
States should be elected to a single
term of six years." The Philodemic
defended the affirmative, while the
Adams upheld the negative.
Those on the Adams' team were:
Robert R. Duncan, Reuben Oppenheimer and Thomas J. Tingley,,
with Ira B. Fader as alternate. The
Philodemic was represented by
John J. Darby, Edward J. Callahan
and Rufus S. Lusk. Each man
made a speech of ten minutes and
a rebuttal of five.
The judges were Hon. Robert M.
Montgomery, Presiding Judge United States Court of Customs Appeals; Willard H. Bronson, Rear
Admiral United States Navy: Hon.
Charles H. Robb, Associate Justice
Court of Appeals, District of Columbia; Hon. Walter I. McCoy, Associate Judge. Supreme Court, District of Columbia; and Hon. James
F. Smith, Associate Judge United
States ,Court of ..Customs Appeals.

The following petition is now being circulated about the University:
"Last year it was the unanimous
sentiment of the Student-Body that
a permanent memorial to Bobby
Layfield should be erected. Because
of the indefinite nature of the University building plans, it was impossible to do so at that time. The
same conditions now exist, but the
following committee appointed by
the Athletic Association feel that
the funds for the memorial should
be collected at the present time
while those who knew Layfield are
still connected with the University.
"Accordingly, at the suggestion
of President Keyser of the Board
of Trustees, the present campaign
is now being made, the resulting
fund to be invested by the trustees
with the understanding that the
permanent memorial of suitable
design is to be erected at the earliest possible time.
"THEODORE STRAUS,
"HIRAM W. WOODWARD,
"FRANKLIN W. SUTTON,
"Committee."
There is no set sum to be given
by the students, and no definite
amount stipplated for each individual contribution. . The smallest
contributions will be as welcome as
the largest; the committee feels that
it is the thought inspired by this
rembrance of Lay-field, and which
will be perpetuated in the memorial,
which is the essential thing.

Besides the individual contributions, sums will be donated by the
Athletic Association, THE NEWSLETTER and other student organizations.

New Material to Be Tested at George
Washington Meet—Relay to Be Main
Event—Coach England Urges
All to Avoid Black List.
A large number of entries has
been made by the Johns Hopkins
track team in the eighth annual
indoor meet of the George Washington University, at Convention
Hall, in Washington, on Saturday,
March 4.
Coach England has decided that
he will send over an almost entirely new collection of runners, so
that all the promising members of
the track team may have experience
in indoor racing. Consequently,
with the exception of the relay
team and a few other men, Hopkins
will be almost entirely represented
by novices,
The most important event of the
meet will be the relay race between
Hopkins and Georgetown. Providing Uhler and Fred Hall recover
from the slight injuries they received in the Georgetown University meet, and that the other members of the relay team keep in good
shape, the event should result in a
walk-away for this University. The
relay team will be made up of F.
Hall, Uhler, Straus, P. Sutton, and
Dempster as first substitute.
Next in interest to the relay to
Hopkins men will be the South
Atlantic Inter-Collegiate Athletic
Association events, particularly the
two-mile run, in which Perkins,
E. L. Smith, Weeks, Holtz and Bullard will run for Hopkins. Considering the recent abLity displayed
by Weeks and Perkins, Hopkins
should win one or all of the first
three places in this event. Likewise, Hopkins is practically sure of
winning a number of points in the
South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association 44o-yard dash,
since Sutton, Straus and Uhler will
be entered.
The entries in the George Washington meet are as follows: Those
entered for long distances are Bullard in the South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association 2-mile
run, Weeks in I-mi.e and 2-mile
open events, A. A. Weech, Fred
Hall and Holtz in the I-mile open
event, Edgett and Kaufman in the
88o-yard run, and E. L. Smith and
J. T. Thompson in the 600-yard
run. In the open 440-yard dash
Dempster, Firor, E. G. Hall,
Stevenson and P. Sutton will run.
Uhler and Pfitsch will sprint for
Hopkins in the South Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic Association
440-yard dash. Those entered in
the 50-yard hurdles are Dempster
and J. T. Thompson. Besides running on the relay. Straus will also
enter the 50-yard dash. The other
entries are Lyman and Stevenson in
the pole-vault, Firor in the highjump, and Tddings and Sonneborn
in the shot-put.Last Thursday Coach England
gave an informal talk to the entire

The Mandolin Club, which for
the first time for many years was
composed entirely of mandolins,
banjos and guitars, played unusually well. Although the support
formerly rendered by piano, violins
and drums was absent, the club was
so arranged that there was a distinct division of parts, the second
Mandolins and guitars forming a
background against which the clear
tones of the first mandolins stood
out very effectively.
Perhaps the most appreciated
number of the evening was the
singing of the quartette. Composed
of four extraordinarily good voices,
all well trained, it gave its first selection, "Luella Lee," with such
striking feeling and harmony that
the audience would not be satisfied
until an encore was given. For
this encore, the quartette gave
"Johnny Smoker," and again met
with uproarious success.
The solo work of the evening was
also unusually good, and was correspondingly appreciated by the
audience. Lotz, a graduate student,
formerly soloist with the Gettysburg Instrumental Club, rendered
Drdla's "Souvenir" with remarkable display of technique and sweetness of tone; Winchester, the leader

favorites, and, like Lotz, evidenced

Dr. Buchner at Detroit Convention.

Dr. Edward F. Buchner took a
prominent part recently in the convention of the Consolidated Educational Associations held at Detroit.
This convention sums up the work
done in all lines of education during
the preceding year, and is the most
important function of its kind held
in the country.
Dr. Buchner, during the convention, acted as secretary of the Committee on Resolutions of the Department of Superintendence of the
National Educational Association.
After his return from the convention, Dr. Buchner went to the
University of Michigan, where he
was the chief speaker at the Hopkins Alumni celebration.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, FEBRUARY 28, 1916.

TOCQUEVILLE TRY-OUTS FRIDAY

BASKET-BALL GAMES NEAR END

Preliminary Contest to be Held to Restrict
Number of Participants in Final
Combat —Only Five-Minute
Speeches Necessary.

Freshman Team Still Heads Interclass
League—Juniori Defeat Sophomores,
and Freshmen Win Against
the Senior Class.

The preliminary contest for the
Tocqueville medal will be held this
Friday at 12, in the Donovan
Room. Four men will be selected
from the participants in these tryouts, and these will compete in
the final contest on Friday, March
31.
In the preliminary trial, it is only
necessary to make a five-minute
speech. The same rules hold for
these speeches, however, as have
been announced for the final competition. The speeches are to be
less general and less emotional
than the general type of orations,
and are each to be limited to a
single topic. While the medal is
to be awarded for excellence in
public speaking, both preliminary
and final contests will differ from
a debate in not being directly controversial.
All those who intend to compete
in the try-outs on Friday should
immediately hand their names to
Dr. French, if they have not already
done so.
The subject for the entire contest will be "The Overthrow of
the Second Republic and the Coup
d'Etat." Specimen sub-topics, which
have been announced as available
for the preliminary contest, are as
follows:
The Causes of the Revolution of
1848.
The Regime of Guigot.
The Personality of Louis Philippe.
Lamartine and the Revolution.
The Republic and the Workingman.
Socialism and the Revolution.
Adolphe Thiers and the Republic.
The Freedom of the Press.
Victor Hugo and the Republic.
"The Napoleonic Ides" in 1848.
Louis Napoleon as a'Republican.

Owing to the fact that the majority of men on the teams of the
inter-class basket-ball league did
not make their appearance in the
gymnasium on February, 22, all
games for that day were postponed.
For this reason the series will not
end until Tuesday and Thursday of
this week.
On Thursday, February 24, two
scheduled games of the series were
played. The first game was between the juniors and sophomores.
This game was quite devoid of any
spectacular features. The juniors
winning by an overwhelming score
of 28 to 7, outplayed their opponents in every particular. Baker,
for the juniors, scored six goals
Love made the majority of points
for the sophomores.
The next game, that between the
seniors and freshmen, was closely
contested. The seniors, as in previous games, did their good playing
in the first half. At the beginning
of the second half the score stood
7 to 9 in favor of the freshmen.
From this point on, the seniors began to weaken and the freshmen
developed an unusual burst of
speed. During this half Cox made
a fine field goal for the freshmen.
Many chances were given the seniors to score in this period, but their
ability to shoot was not equal to
their opportunities. The freshmen
won by the score of 17 to 12.
The freshmen are still at the
head of the league. The standing
of the teams is as follows:

Meeting of Society Postponed.

GOOD CLOTHES—WEYFORTH'S

The meeting of the Engineering
Society, which was set for. last
Thursday, was postponed, due to
the inability of Mr. Quincy Bent
to be present. Mr. Bent is assistant to President Wood of the
Maryland Steel Company and had
to be at Sparrows Point with Mr.
Grace, President of the Bethlehem
Steel Company, who was here on
an inspection trip. The topic for
discussion was to have been "Gas
Manufacturing, Coke Ovens, and
By-Product Recovery."
The meeting, which was also to
be addressed by Mr. F. H. Wagner,
chief engineer of the Bartlett Hayward Company, will be held shortly.
